snippet: Some products are as simple as covers for the buttons of a device; others are sophisticated software programs that can turn off texting capacity in a moving car.
abstract: Tips are given to parents on products that measure and filter how their children use technology.

headline.main: Tools to Control a Child’s Technology
headline.print_headline: Tools to Control a Child’s Technology

snippet: Perhaps it was not surprising that Gilad Shalit would show up at City Hall on Monday, the sixth anniversary of his capture, to visit Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for a brief ceremony.

snippet: Apple, which once bragged that that its Mac computer "Doesn't get PC viruses," recently tweaked its marketing message to read: "Built to be safe." Antivirus makers have been quick to call the tweak an official admission by Apple that this computer...
abstract: Apple, which once bragged that that its Mac computer "Doesn't get PC viruses," recently tweaked its marketing message to read: "Built to be safe." Antivirus makers have been quick to call the tweak an official admission by Apple that this computers are no longer immune from attacks common to PCs running Windows. Or is it just the latest instance of antivirus makers over-hyping a threat to sell more product because Apple is selling significantly more computers than ever before?

headline.main: Apple Tweaks Its 'We're Safe' Message and Antivirus Makers Take Notice

snippet: The Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island over the weekend ranged from electronics-loving, D.J.-rooted pop to hand-played, guitar-centered rock.
abstract: Jon Pareles reviews performances at the two-day Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island.

headline.main: Two Days Contain a Multitude of Mood Swings

snippet: In "Brave," Pixar gives us the first Disney princess who doesn't need or want a prince - and it doesn't matter at all that the princes in question are all dolts.

snippet: A move by Apple to secure high-quality aluminum from Australia for iPad cases was one of many incidents that gradually convinced Microsoft that it needed to create its own tablet computer, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times.
abstract: A move by Apple to secure high-quality aluminum from Australia for iPad cases was one of many incidents that gradually convinced Microsoft that it needed to create its own tablet computer, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times.
